instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> still 5v after all USB-C where changed
threads.message:
This board is showing 5.2V on the charger. The USB C Controllers have already been replaced and the issue persits. 

What do you check/how do you find the responsible port? And what could be some more possible causes?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> still 5v after all USB-C where changed
threads.message:
Any history available?
Did replace the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> with exact same termination?
C00 and B03 are not compatible, for example...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> still 5v after all USB-C where changed
threads.message: What voltage do you get on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>? And yes, hopefully, you replaced with the same firmware C00 or B03...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> still 5v after all USB-C where changed
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> still 5v after all USB-C where changed
threads.message: There is your problem you will NOT get 20 volts without PP3v3 it has to be present. Resistance to ground on that line?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> still 5v after all USB-C where changed
threads.message:
Do you get 5V at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>?
If not, post diode mode (red probe at ground) at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> and F7000.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> still 5v after all USB-C where changed
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is shorted.. The SMC is the problem... should we try to recplace it, or not

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> still 5v after all USB-C where changed
threads.message: Is the SMC definitely the short? If so, replacing it should fix the issue

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> still 5v after all USB-C where changed
threads.message:
If short is gone when remove the SMC, change it.
Remember to use one from same 00281 donor board...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> still 5v after all USB-C where changed
threads.message: Now, we changed the SMC and the short is gone. Still 5v on the charger tho.. I noticed that all ports except one draws about 150mA. Only one is drawing just 11mA. Does that tell us somethng ? or is it irrelevant

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> still 5v after all USB-C where changed
